newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan life, non-life insurers to get licences today.
newsitem.headline: Japan life, non-life insurers to get licences today.

text.p: Japan's Ministry of Finance (MOF) will give 17 life and non-life insurance companies licences to do business in each others' fields later on Tuesday, a ministry official said. He did not give further details.

Earlier this month, 11 Japanese non-life and six life insurance companies submitted applications to the ministry to start operating in each other's turf. They plan to start their new business in October, industry sources said.
An amendment to Japanese laws on the insurance market, which took effect in April, allows insurers to conduct both life and non-life insurance business through subsidiaries.
Jiji news agency reported that the ministry would withhold issuing licences for the accident insurance business to the insurers' subsidiaries.

Vice Finance Minister Tadashi Ogawa said last week the ministry, if necessary, may put conditions on the entry of domestic insurance firms' units into the so-called third sector, which covers accidents and health care.

Washington and Tokyo have been at odds over the entry of Japanese insurers' subsidiaries into the third-sector niche market, accident insurance in particular. Foreign insurers have a strong market position in that sector.
Several rounds of talks have been held to resolve the situation, and new talks are due some time in September.
